keyTakeAways: The US government is attempting to deport Mahmoud Khalil, a legal permanent resident and Palestine solidarity activist, based on claims that his presence has adverse foreign policy consequences.
Khalil was detained in March 2025 and missed the birth of his first child, highlighting the personal toll of immigration enforcement on activists.
The government alleges Khalil concealed his work with UNRWA on visa and Green Card applications to justify deportation.
A federal district court in New Jersey granted Khalil’s release in a habeas corpus petition, asserting that the government cannot detain individuals for expressing political opinions.

If the Board of Immigration Appeals affirms the immigration judge’s decision, the case will likely be appealed to a circuit court on constitutional grounds.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mahmoud Khalil, a Palestinian solidarity activist and legal permanent resident, was detained in March 2025 after his activism at Columbia University sparked immigration enforcement actions. The government has sought to deport him, alleging that his presence has adverse foreign policy consequences and that he concealed work with UNRWA on immigration forms. A lower court in New Jersey ruled in favor of Khalil, releasing him from detention in a habeas corpus petition, which lawyers are now urging the US appeals court to uphold. The ACLU argues that the government’s use of immigration law to silence political speech is unconstitutional. A separate judge ruled the broader Trump administration crackdown on Palestine solidarity activists unlawful, violating free speech rights. The case remains ongoing, with both the habeas petition and the deportation process under appeal, highlighting a deep conflict between immigration policy and free expression.
title: Lawyers urge US appeals court to uphold Mahmoud Khalil’s release order
